ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Did a lot of readings on Indian Philosophy which I typically would not have read through the philosophical lens. 
Better understanding of the origins of some philosophies I have been exposed to throughout my life.
Developed insight into philosophical traditions in Sanskrit literature in a way that I had not previously been exposed. Particular emphasis on non-dualism.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
Interesting readings
Good class discussion
Fun to lead a class discussion 

Weaknesses:
Can be hard to find some of the required texts that weren't provided in canvas
Some readings later in the course were pretty difficult to understand

Strengths- Professor is knowledgeable and the syllabus is uniqu
No weaknesses to note

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes ! aleksandar / professor uskokov is amazing (caring / understanding of external factors preventing assignment completion / encourages you to push on your own + others' ideas) // the class discussions could've been better facilitated, but I think this just comes with time!
Yes if you would like a gentle introduction into philosophy. It was helpful to have a blend of spiritual and philosophy-dense readings because it was easier to digest.
Absolutely. Its a wonderful class with a very reasonable amount of work in which you will learn a lot
